pull_request.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

pullrequest.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

content.raw:
The current cmake looks like it searches for fluidix, and if found builds the plugin. This is a good approach, and does not hamper licensing since we are not including any of the Fluidix code. Fluiidix is also not a mandatory dependency, so nothing will break. 

It will be difficult to test via jenkins, but I'm okay with that. This is a very advanced feature that is only accessible through compilation from source.
content.html:
The current cmake looks like it searches for fluidix, and if found builds the plugin. This is a good approach, and does not hamper licensing since we are not including any of the Fluidix code. Fluiidix is also not a mandatory dependency, so nothing will break.

It will be difficult to test via jenkins, but I'm okay with that. This is a very advanced feature that is only accessible through compilation from source.

content.raw:
So to summarize:

1. cmake
2. cmake
3. cmake

I don't think it's a scalable solution to our cmake problems to push everything into gazebo. Maybe we could use catkin to set up all the build dependencies and environment path variables?
content.html:
So to summarize:

  1. cmake
  2. cmake
  3. cmake

I don't think it's a scalable solution to our cmake problems to push everything into gazebo. Maybe we could use catkin to set up all the build dependencies and environment path variables?

pull_request.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

pullrequest.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

content.raw: I'm curious to hear what @nkoenig thinks about this. Are the benefits of distributing a plugin that may have limited use due to its reliance on closed source software worth the extra space it takes up in the repo?
content.html: I'm curious to hear what @nkoenig thinks about this. Are the benefits of distributing a plugin that may have limited use due to its reliance on closed source software worth the extra space it takes up in the repo?

pull_request.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

pullrequest.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

content.raw:
our thoughts were:

 1. not having to pull in yet another repository seemed attractive mainly because there's less cmake wrangling.
 1. being in the same cmake project made it easier to create unit tests. We had *issues* (required more cmake wrangling) when trying to make unit tests for fluids simulation as a separate repository.
 1. make development process easier (less cmake/system path wrangling).  Develop / build from source from one repository is probably easier to manage than building from source from multiple repositories.
content.html:
our thoughts were:

  1. not having to pull in yet another repository seemed attractive mainly because there's less cmake wrangling.
  2. being in the same cmake project made it easier to create unit tests. We had issues (required more cmake wrangling) when trying to make unit tests for fluids simulation as a separate repository.
  3. make development process easier (less cmake/system path wrangling). Develop / build from source from one repository is probably easier to manage than building from source from multiple repositories.

pull_request.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

pullrequest.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

content.raw:
I agree that the license is an issue. What is the advantage of putting this here in gazebo instead of keeping it in a separate repository?

I don't think having it in gazebo would make it that much easier users to access. We certainly won't be supporting this in our debian packages due to the licensing issues, so they will have to build from source anyway.
content.html:
I agree that the license is an issue. What is the advantage of putting this here in gazebo instead of keeping it in a separate repository?

I don't think having it in gazebo would make it that much easier users to access. We certainly won't be supporting this in our debian packages due to the licensing issues, so they will have to build from source anyway.

pull_request.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

pullrequest.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

content.raw:
My one hesitation about this plugin is that Fluidix is not open-source. http://onezero.ca/license-agreement-non-com/

It would be awesome to integrate fluid simulation with Gazebo, but the Fluidix non-commercial license agreement could be an obstacle to the widespread usage of this plugin. There are open source [fluid simulators](http://www.rchoetzlein.com/fluids3/?page_id=13), and it might be more useful to the world if the fluid plugin backend was freely available and instantly downloadable.
content.html:
My one hesitation about this plugin is that Fluidix is not open-source. http://onezero.ca/license-agreement-non-com/

It would be awesome to integrate fluid simulation with Gazebo, but the Fluidix non-commercial license agreement could be an obstacle to the widespread usage of this plugin. There are open source fluid simulators, and it might be more useful to the world if the fluid plugin backend was freely available and instantly downloadable.

pull_request.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

pullrequest.title: Andrei Haidu GSOC fluid plugin with Fluidix

content.html:
wow, that's a lot of h's. Fun note, apparently in C++11 this is no longer necessary and about as efficient as using std::pow. (http://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/numeric/math/pow)

Anyway, if we're not living in C++11-landia, consider a helper function like this (from http://www.overclockers.com/forums/showthread.php/380512-Wow-a-big-C-C-code-speedup!!!):

double intpow( double base, int exponent ) { int i; double out = base; for( i=1 ; i < exponent ; i++ ) { out *= base; } return out; }

it's just a bit more readable :)
